titleInfo.title: Emma Dell Peters oral history interview

mods.abstract: Peters give an account of her great-grandparents' purchases as slaves, and discuss slaves' religion, the treatment of slaves, and female slaves who bore children for their white masters. The interview records spirituals that Peters learned from her grandparents, and her accounts of illnesses, funeral customs, early jobs she held, poverty in her youth, discipline and life in her large family, traditions of Sunday prayer, and crops grown by her parents.; Peters discusses the impact of Civil Rights legislation. Remarks of her father, Willie Jackson, are included.
mods.note: This collection includes materials accessioned as Mss. 4700.0283. A digital version of the index (pdf) exists for duplication purposes. A digital version of the audio recording (mp3) exists for duplication purposes and public access in the Special Collections Reading Room. Interview conducted by Adrienne LaCour.

Resident of Four Corners, an unincorporated community south of Franklin, St. Mary Parish, Louisiana. Emma Dell Peters lived on Sterling Plantation; her great-grandparents were slaves. For 26 years, Peters worked as a cook in the school system.

name.namePart: Louisiana State University (Baton Rouge, La.). T. Harry Williams Center for Oral History
